TextEquiv.Unicode: in this fellowship we are sanctlfied from
al filth or uncleannesse, being cleansed,
and holie in Christ our Lorde,
Now followeth the tenth article of
our beleefe, which is: The forgivenesse
of sinnes. The second fruit or commo
ditie of our beleefe in God the father,
the son, and the holy ghost, is here set
foorth, that is, the remission of sinnes,
which, although it be cotained in sanc
tification spoken of in the last article,
is in this place notwithstanding more
lively expressed. Without the Church
as it were without the arke of Noe is
no salvatio: but in ye Church, I meane
in the felowship of Christ, & the saints
is ful forgivenesse of al offences. That
this may be the better understoode I
will divide it into some partes,
First of al it is needeful to acknow
ledge & confesse, that we are sinners, &
that by nature, and our owne proper
merits, we are the children of wrath &
damnation. For S. John doth not in
vaine nor without a cause call everie
one a liar that saith he hath no sin. And
God which knoweth the harts of men
hath commaunded us even till the last
gaspe to pray, saying: Forgive us our
debts. Moreover, in the Gospell wee
have two excellent examples of men o
penly confessing their sins to God, the
prodigall sonne, I say, and the Publi
can in S. Luke. Let us therfore thinke
that we are all sinners, as Paule also
taught: yea, as he hath evidently proo
ved in the first chap, to the Romanes, &
let us freely confesse to God our sinnes
with David in the 32. & 52. Psal, say
ing: Wy sinne have I made knowen to
thee, et mine iniduitie I have not hid.
I have saide: I will confesse mine un
righteousues against my selfe, et thou
hast forgiven the iniduitie of mine
offence, Have mercie on me G God,
accordingto thy great merey, Ze. The

in this fellowship we are sanctlfied from al filth or uncleannesse, being cleansed, and holie in Christ our Lorde, Now followeth the tenth article of our beleefe, which is: The forgivenesse of sinnes. The second fruit or commo ditie of our beleefe in God the father, the son, and the holy ghost, is here set foorth, that is, the remission of sinnes, which, although it be cotained in sanc tification spoken of in the last article, is in this place notwithstanding more lively expressed. Without the Church as it were without the arke of Noe is no salvatio: but in ye Church, I meane in the felowship of Christ, & the saints is ful forgivenesse of al offences. That this may be the better understoode I will divide it into some partes, First of al it is needeful to acknow ledge & confesse, that we are sinners, & that by nature, and our owne proper merits, we are the children of wrath & damnation. For S. John doth not in vaine nor without a cause call everie one a liar that saith he hath no sin. And God which knoweth the harts of men hath commaunded us even till the last gaspe to pray, saying: Forgive us our debts. Moreover, in the Gospell wee have two excellent examples of men o penly confessing their sins to God, the prodigall sonne, I say, and the Publi can in S. Luke. Let us therfore thinke that we are all sinners, as Paule also taught: yea, as he hath evidently proo ved in the first chap, to the Romanes, & let us freely confesse to God our sinnes with David in the 32. & 52. Psal, say ing: Wy sinne have I made knowen to thee, et mine iniduitie I have not hid. I have saide: I will confesse mine un righteousues against my selfe, et thou hast forgiven the iniduitie of mine offence, Have mercie on me G God, accordingto thy great merey, Ze. The
called them sainctes, which for their
faith are sanctified by the bloud and
spirit of God. Also this word Commu
nion is verie evident and comfortalbe.
For first the meaning thereof is that
betwirt god & us there is a communi
on, that is a felowship & participation,
and so consequently a parting betwirt
us and all good and heavenly things.
And then also we understand, that we
are fellowes and partakers with all ye
Saincts that are living either in hea
ven or on earth. For we are memders
of the under one heade Christ. For the
Apostle John saith: That which wee
have seene and heard we declare unto
you, that yee also may have fellow ship
with us, and that your fellowship may
be with the father, and his sonne lesus
Christ. Hereunto appertayneth that
trimme similitude of the bodie & mem
bers under one heade, which ye Apostle
Paule handleth at large in deede: but
what is hee that can worthily enough
set foorth the great goodnesse of Gods
gift & benefit, in that we are made fel
low partners of God, with whom we
are most neerely conioined, and have a
part in al his good & heavenly thinges
what can be more delightfull to our
eares, than to heare that all the saints
as well in heaven as in earth, are our
brethren, and that we again are mem
bers, partners, and felowes with the
Blessed be God which hath so liberally
bestowed his blessing on us in Christ
his sonne. To this place belongeth the
discourse uppon the Sacramentes, of
which, and of the Church, I meane at
an other time more fully to intreate,
This for the present time is sufficient,
For this ye I have said doth abundatly
enough expresse & set out the fruite of
faith in the father, the sonne, & the holy
ghost, to wit, ye we have participation
with God, and al the saints, and that

called them sainctes, which for their faith are sanctified by the bloud and spirit of God. Also this word Commu nion is verie evident and comfortalbe. For first the meaning thereof is that betwirt god & us there is a communi on, that is a felowship & participation, and so consequently a parting betwirt us and all good and heavenly things. And then also we understand, that we are fellowes and partakers with all ye Saincts that are living either in hea ven or on earth. For we are memders of the under one heade Christ. For the Apostle John saith: That which wee have seene and heard we declare unto you, that yee also may have fellow ship with us, and that your fellowship may be with the father, and his sonne lesus Christ. Hereunto appertayneth that trimme similitude of the bodie & mem bers under one heade, which ye Apostle Paule handleth at large in deede: but what is hee that can worthily enough set foorth the great goodnesse of Gods gift & benefit, in that we are made fel low partners of God, with whom we are most neerely conioined, and have a part in al his good & heavenly thinges what can be more delightfull to our eares, than to heare that all the saints as well in heaven as in earth, are our brethren, and that we again are mem bers, partners, and felowes with the Blessed be God which hath so liberally bestowed his blessing on us in Christ his sonne. To this place belongeth the discourse uppon the Sacramentes, of which, and of the Church, I meane at an other time more fully to intreate, This for the present time is sufficient, For this ye I have said doth abundatly enough expresse & set out the fruite of faith in the father, the sonne, & the holy ghost, to wit, ye we have participation with God, and al the saints, and that
